Chicago's Best Burger? So tonight for Easter dinner, urlLink John and I (and others) were at a restaurant debating the menu. "CHICAGO'S BEST BURGER" the menu proclaimed. Well, well, well. We had nothing of that. Best burger? If this is true, tell me: - How can you put a price tag on the ONE hamburger that is the best in Chicago? If the one I am eating is the best, does that mean the one the guy next to me is eating is not quite as good? Or is it better? I want to know! The name is misleading. It should be the "best hamburger s in Chicago." Fix it. - The only way a burger can be deemed "the best" is if it has been eaten. If it's not eaten, then what was it, the best-looking burger? best smelling? And don't tell me they could eat half of the burger and tell. What if the second half is grossly undercooked, or has a large squirming tapeworm in it? Human finger? Didn't anyone else see that episode of Buffy? Therefore you cannot base the quality of an individual burger. The name should now be " Chicago's best burger recipe(or preparation). " - I live in Minneapolis. How am I eating Chicago's best burger if I'm not in Chicago? This is not Chicago's best burger. It may be the best burger FROM Chicago; and since it's not the burger that is the best, but the recipe, it is in actuality the " Best burger recipe(or preparation) FROM Chicago. " - But wait! Who is to say it's the best? It is not mathematical, it was voted. Not only was it voted, but it was voted by an uneven representation of demographics! Therefore it is in actuality " Voted the best burger recipe (or preparation) FROM Chicago, as decided subjectively by a panel of individuals, having no basis in fact. Choose for yourself. " I am all about Political Correctness, and THIS my friends is not PC.

SOMETHING I AM WONDERING ABOUT: On the bus today there was this couple. Kinda ugly, both of them, nothing to write home about, but they were being very affectionate and I thought it was kinda adorable, but then I realized a few things: 1: It was one-sided. He had his hand on her neck and back, rubbing her, squeezing her and such. Every once in a while she giggled, but I have seen the behavior before, it's something of a "you're mine" pet. The kind you do when you run your fingers through your retriever's hair. It disturbed me. 2: He didn't look at her. Granted, he might suffer neck strain if he did, but the entire time he looked around the bus. I was listening to music and trying to ignore the scene, but I caught him staring right at me out of the corner of my eye a few times. Now what is that? Is that the "See this? She's mine!" stare? Like 1, I have seen this before too. You look around to make sure nobody's looking at your girl. If you see someone looking at your girl, you check to make sure there is no eye contact. She was not looking at anyone, I could tell. She made it a point to look above and between people. I'm probably paranoid, but the look in his eyes and the behavior I saw I've seen before and I didn't like it one bit. Was I wrong to want to punch him just for my assumptions? o_O

Concerned Observer: As Christians know, aureoles (or halos) are fluffy ring-shaped clouds that hover above the heads of Jesus, Mary, and all the saints. In every day life, the spiritual observer sees halos above the heads of righteous people, and sees devil horns above the heads of sinners. The secular observer sees no difference. The Devil cannot stand goodness! To mock the Lord, he has created counterfeit halos in nuclear explosions, and rubber prophylactics. They are equally destructive. Atomic warfare has gone out of fashion, so Satan has no choice but to promote condoms. If they looked satanic, people wouldn't sin and use them. But fornication seems almost righteous when any Tom, Dick, or Harry can claim that little halo, if only for a moment. The Bible clearly states that no Christian would use one! Praise the Word! Sister Rossetta

urlLink Libby asked the question "How do you just... stop... doing something that has become a habit?" and that reminds me of something I've been wondering for quite a while... I've always prided myself on self-diagnosis; on being able to fix whatever it is that is wrong with me, but that just isn't so recently. As I grow older, I grow more wary. It is to the point where I cannot even believe myself. So how the hell do I trick myself? I can't outsmart myself to unlearn a behavior, or learn a new one. I'm wise to my own tricks, and thus am stuck how I am with no chance of conscious change. There is such a fine line between being normal and being too smart for your own good. Balancing on that line is the ability to do anything you want, mentally... the ability to teach the old dog new tricks. But for me, that ability is gone. Perhaps this dog is too old to learn new tricks, and where I was when I stumbled across that line is where I'm left to sit for the rest of my life. Holy crap, I'm beginning to see how it's so easy to get melodramatic on a blogger. You don't mean to, but it just starts coming out as "woe is me," and again, here I am sounding like a head case. woo?

In the last half hour of the day I thought I would give you all a thrilling recap of my Friday, April 5th, nineteen ninety twelve. Around midnight, I passed out from being sick and exhausted from a harrrd week of, well, classes. Okay so it wasn't hard, but it still tired me out cause I'm sick. I get up at quarter to eight and hop on here for a while, then go downstairs for some banana bread and to finish my game of Madden. Then, it's off to my brother's for a long day of driving in his peacup, and napping while he ran in places. Then I bought a DVD; then we made more stops (one to the liquor store) and eventually came home. Left around noon and came back around six. So, he bought his DirecTV and it got set up. Played some Virtua Fighter 2 with him (and drank) and Pokemon Stadium 2 with his daughter, and then we watched about 600 channels of tv (whilst drinking). After the kids went to bed, Skinemax came on and we watched some Emmanuelle something or other, a softcore porn about a hot blonde with mind control devices and pierced nipples. I give it four stars. Then I came home. And now I want to pass out again. I'm tired. First, I gotta go pick on a certain drunk girl some more... ;)

What's my problem? I sit on my ass for half a semester and then midterms come around, I'm stressed out (for reasons other than midterms) in fact, I can't even study for midterms... but I take them, expect to get a C or worse, and end up getting 102%. I just realized something. I'm all alone. I looked out my window tonight on the way home and saw a sorority house: "Technical Women Students." Why don't I get that? Every minority gets their own group, their own club, somewhere to fit in. The only group for fat people and heavy drinkers end in "Anonymous," and the sole purpose is to STRIP YOU of those traits. Society just wants me to be a normal, boring, young adult middle class white male with no known distinguishing characteristics. I'm not a frat boy. I'm not stupid and slutty or average looking enough. Plus, I hate beer, and I suck at frisbee. My parents aren't rich, and I don't like the concept of pledging. I don't embarass myself for acceptance. I just sit on my ass and ask for it while doing nothing. I'm an English major. What do I do? I could be in an artsy book club, but I don't read. I'm not a pseudo-intellectual I'm an actual fucking intellectual. I'm smart but only as smart as I am. I do not act any smarter. I do not use lots of big words and I don't quote people. I do not fit in with my own group. I have no group. As "up myself" as I am, I'm nowhere near where I should be and that is sad. I need some horn rimmed glasses and a black turtle neck and start writing poetry because this whole "being unique" bullshit is not all it's cracked up to be.

BATS!@!@#@%@$^%&*U%^%$$#@ All right so my house is special, yall. You know how lots of houses have little doggie doors? Well not so much because of skinny burglars, but in the movies all houses have doggie doors. Anyway, my house has a special bat door. Every summer is bat season; every winter, mouse season. Like clockwork, there's another bat in my basement. There will be about five in all this year, as in every other year. They are pretty good about staying in the basement, but sometimes they don't. DATELINE CIRCA 1985 CE, my brothers and I are playing on the hide-a-bed in the den (I think), when a great big black thing comes up from the basement. I, being the brave little five-year-old I am, dive under the hide-a-bed and, well, hide. This was my earliest bat memory. DATELINE LIKE A FEW YEARS AGO, I was washing my face down in the basement, as there is no working sink above the basement, when I see something moving in the washer to my left. My glasses were off so it was just black and furry and moving, so I slammed the cover, assuming it was a bat or something bat-like. Lo and behold, one cold-rinse cycle later, the shivering, unconscious bat was removed from the washer and released into the wild, alive. Good stuff. DATELINE I FORGOT, MAYBE TWO YEARS BEFORE THE LAST ONE, I was sitting on my computer chit chatting with people when a bat came up. Me, being the brave upper-teen teenager I was, hit the deck and came upstairs, signing online up here. I am sure some of the people I knew back then may recall this. It was quite funny, oh it was indeed. Later on, as I gathered the courage, I hunted this damned bat. It was no floozie bat, it did not go home the next morning. I grabbed my AWESOME blow gun and shot its wing with a blow dart. Eventually it flew away so I can't prove that I have good aim, but I thought I got him (sorry Kelly). I am pretty sure he/she/it was ok though. However, I got a blow dart stuck in my ceiling. Kinda sucked. Got it out though, but I believe Josh and/or Sam broke the mouthpiece of the gun as it was on my floor, since I am a messy bastard. Anywho, I can't shoot anymore bats, b'gorrah, and I was fin ta, too, to have lunch for tomorrow.... TTFN.

Vanilla Sky So I saw this movie tonight. I didn't really want to see it, as I have honed the ability to tell a shitty movie from its commercials, and this movie had some of the worst. It's a damned shame that the advertising was so horrible, because I really really liked it. Now, I'm still as skeptical as ever, and fully realized this was just another head trip of a movie witholding vital information in an attempt to throw you off making you think you've been fooled, but the ways Vanilla Sky worked were very new and, erm, for lack of a better term, kicked ass. One reviewer for the film had said there were too many twists and turns, so many that they lost their effectiveness. Listening to him I thought "Wow! That really sucks!" After seeing it, however, I cannot believe how thoroughly he missed the point. For those keeping score, he was some Minneapolis News reviewer, I think. Anyway, one thing I noticed about Vanilla Sky was that every time something happened that I wanted to talk about, I had no chance to say so. The plot just moved too quickly. I couldn't avert my eyes for a second without missing something -- and not everything missed was all that important, either. That doesn't matter; what matters is that I was on my heels for most of the movie and wasn't given time to fully think about what was happening. To my credit, though, I almost figured it out. As I said, certain things were omitted to make you feel like you weren't smart enough to get it. To avoid spoiling the movie, I will avoid spoiling the movie, but anyway... Part two of this funky rhyme, G(Something of a spoiler, indeed): I caught the eeriest feeling when Aames finally found Sophia, up until he woke up the next morning. What feeling? Well, the feeling that I could relate to his life as it existed at that moment. The way she treated him, his reaction... it was soopa powerful for me because I know what that feels like. All right, now, to lighten the mood (for me, not for you, asshead), here's a dancing skeleton:

The Origins of AlphaBean: Part 1 (It's in reverse order, remember?) Q: "Why do you prefer Bean over Scott?" A: It's a many-faceted explanation, which is undoubtedly too complex for your simple minds. Just kidding. First of all, I like it as a nickname. It suits me, it's silly... and it's not "Scottie." I hate hate hate being called "Scottie" and you may ask 'well then why did you go by Scottie when you first came around?' and I will answer you that it was the only thing I could come up with that in the tiniest bit described who I was. I have found the moniker to do so in AlphaBean. Also, in the past year, I have grown ashamed of the name Scott. It has come to signify things I can't comprehend and that disgust me. If I do not see myself as Scott, I cannot fall into that same hole. At least I fucking hope that's true ;) I have another reason, one more personal... but I'm not going to be a Drama Bean here and type it out. All you need to know is that I prefer to be called Bean than Scott. At least online. For some reason, having anyone call me one thing after calling me another for as long as they've known me, just doesn't sit well. I'm not a big fan of change. That is all.

What's an AlphaBean? Okay so Dana (link to the right) questioned a couple of things tonight: 1) Why do I prefer being called Bean over Scott, and 2) What the fuck is an AlphaBean? Well let's go in reverse order: 32 years ago on the streets of Manila, there lived a little pauper boy named Scott. That was me. Except it wasn't Manila, it was Minnesota. And it wasn't the street... it was my couch. And it wasn't 32 years ago... it was, like, three. Oh, and I was never a pauper. I am a PRINCE. You hear me? PRINCE!!!! Anyway, I had just bought a laptop (which has long since been destroyed), and also bought the game Worms 2. I was the daddy at that game, and my squad, whose names I've forgotten, were led by one Alpha Bean. Basically, he was the leader, and his name was Bean. He fucking ruled. He was usually the only worm I had left on the more tricky, difficult levels. ANYWAY. I had been known on the internet as Scottie, ScottieW, ScoTTieX, and then Spifferz. Spifferz was so gay, but I was told it was close enough to ScoTTieX that it was ok. Well I made a drastic change and adopted the name of my favorite worm, AlphaBean. Now, I am world-famous and so is my name. In fact, even javascript fuckers have stolen my name to use on their code. That is irrelevant. Basically, I'm now me, and you all have been graced by my glorious humility and character. I'm so special that I think I'll wait until tomorrow for part 1, so that this doesn't end up being too long of a post.

Mr Deeds FUCK THAT. Not worth a Beanie Review. It was a remake, but all they did was threw some jokes on top of it instead of actually doing anything. It seemed more like a home video of Sandler and his friends than an actual movie. I wasted a lot of money on the movie and I WANT IT BACK. :( Lilo and Stitch I loved this movie. It was intelligent and pretty mature, with more cohesion despite the twist-ful finish than 'Deeds." I totally love the mischievous little alien and see myself slightly in that role, except I'm big, human, not a cartoon, and not infinitely intelligent. Anyway, the best part of the film was when Stitch uses his powers to be constructive at the request of Lilo. I'm not spoiling anything, but look out for it, and you'll see what I mean. I went to see the movie in Thunder Bay at some big theater with huge screens, and it was all kids (not many though), and John and I laughed our asses off when the kids didn't and it was awkward. I want you all to watch three movies: Lilo and Stitch, The Bourne Identity, and The Shipping News. Yup.

And now I'm back... from outer space... you just walked in to....etc... All right well I just returned from Canada and upper Minnesota on vacation, and I had written out a list of interesting things I noticed about Canada, but I don't know where the list is right now so I will post that later. I just want to say hi, and talk about casinos. We stopped at two casinos, one to and one from our destination. Both times I couldn't help but get depressed, as though I was in a hospital surrounded by unhappy, sick and dying people. I couldn't even handle it without alcohol, which is why I got quite depressed sober the second time around. First of all there are the slots. This is where Social Security checks are wasted. In Canada, the elderly Americans take buses to buy their prescriptions cheaper, and on the way back they sit at the slots for HOURS and HOURS just throwing their money away. Outside of the occasional new 18 year old hanging out with friends, I haven't seen one person smile at the slots. NOT EVEN THE WINNERS! Jackpots are won, hundreds and hundreds of dollars... yet these people just stare X_X it's depressing. These people need friends worse than I do. That leads me to my next casino area: The tables. This is where the most serious of the serious stay. Blackjack is what got people killed in the Old West, and if concealed weapons were legal today I am sure there would be many gambling-related deaths. If you take a hit when you're not supposed to or stand on a low number you gain a handful of enemies for life, because it's not just a game. The heads of the casino march in and out of the table room with armed guards watching over your every move. You can't talk or you might distract somebody. Your actions must be crisp and mathematical and you must obey strict rules. It's a game! Holy Jesus I think I took my last trip to the casino yesterday. The Shipping News I loved this movie. I think maybe I was tricked by the quirkiness of it all... of all the characters and all the situations... Judi Dench did things I'd never expect from someone who was knighted... and many times I looked at the screen thinking... "what the fuck?" I've been a big big huge fan of Julianne Moore as long as I can remember. She's just ungodly beautiful even at 40+ and she's a better actress than most of the trash out there (Julia Roberts). I've been a huge fan of Kevin Spacey since Outbreak, but lately I've gotten tired of him. Especially K-Pax. That was the worst movie ever. However, in Shipping News, he's solid. Granted, he was overshadowed by his supporting cast, but not buy much. The character he portrayed was complex enough that just saying he was this way or that way wouldn't suffice... so he did well. Again... wonderful supporting cast. This movie felt very real and if it wasn't for Moore's statuesque larger-than-life beauty, I would never have thought about it being a movie. The Shipping News was a bit slow to start, and it never really speeds up too much, but it plays like a home movie you don't want to rush, if you can put your mind in the right place. If you're looking for profundity or mindless action look elsewhere. The shame with The Shipping News is, while it's not an action movie, I am sure it would have been so much better in the theater. The 55" TV and surround sound stereo just couldn't capture it like a theater would. You know, I went to see The Royal Tenenbaums last week and never reviewed it... I suppose I will eventually. Also... I know I review videos and I think "The Bourne Identity" was the only new release I actually have discussed... but then I'm not all that into seeing new movies, or videos for that matter. My family rents maybe five videos a week and I only watch at most one of them. So... whatever. It's something to post when you have nothing else to post. I do have a question, though... I have been trying to figure out a system to post stories and allow people to critique them online... does anyone have any suggestions on how to do that?

All right so I watch a lot of TV and a lot of movies, and I see people with whom, personality-wise, I can relate. They mean well, but they put foot in mouth often, have major flaws, but in the end, while this gets them in trouble... they always end up all right, no harm done. In the real world, I see everyone trying to be cooler than everybody else. People don't want to say what they're thinking, or say what they feel, they don't want to deal with the consequences, and they don't want to "take any risks." Tactless people with heart-on-sleeve are often looked down upon, usually because the majority of them are viewed to be substance abusers of some sort, or clinically insane. Anyway... I'm noticing more and more that I can deal with glaring lapses of personality, and even with stupidity to a point, and generally only dislike people for what they do -- not who they are. I have grown accustomed to tuning out tactless comments, and can converse quite well with some of the more serious cases. Still, though... I think life needs to more imitate art... to accomodate the intellectually clumsy instead of forcing more and more people to conform and close off. I'm a fuckup but I'm not a bad person, at least I don't think I am, and I'd really like to have a place in this world. Do I need to start a support group for fuckups? As some of you know, one of the things I believe in is laying the cards on the table... to let people see inside without having to dig, beg, or guess. What I say is what comes to mind at that exact moment. Sometimes I mean it, sometimes I don't... it gets me in trouble often, but how I am in real life is the exact opposite: I say nothing for fear of how it will affect me. With close friends and family I will say what I want to say and sometimes that gets me in huge big trouble as it does on here or anywhere else... but if I didn't speak my mind, I wouldn't speak at all. I just try convincing myself that some of the good I say makes up for some of the bad I say. I want to see some more people talk out their ass so I wouldn't have to feel so alone.

Two review-type thingies. The Bourne Identity : Matt Damon an action star? It's true. He pulled it off as well as anyone else could, and gave the character the right amount of, what, innocence? I don't know if I could like him in many action movies -- especially since I am not a big Damon fan, but I loved this movie. It was not overacted or CGI-laden, just a good solid action movie with a bit of thinking involved. Now, I will have to see TBI again since midway through the film I was afflicted with too-much-mello-yello syndrome and I will spare the gory details, just rest assured the film seemed to run another four hours. Jurassic Park II was forever ruined for me for that reason, though it was a shitty movie to start with, but I still enjoyed TBI as much as possible. HOWEVER! When the movie was over I was like "FINALLY!" but the line... well it didn't move. It took another 10 minutes to get out of the theater, and when I got out of the theater I took advantage of my size and maneuverability, and made a mad dash through all the small women. I felt kinda bad... but then, I also didn't care. It happens. OBSERVATION: That movie had lots of old people, most on dates, but quite a few on their own. I was surprised... but then I also noticed there were many young kids there; leaving the theater I heard a group of Jr. High age girls saying "But... what happened here, and who was that?" and I had a chuckle. Blackhawk Down : Wasn't such a bad movie, but interestingly enough that movie has made me think more than any other movie I've seen this year. Seriously... there were maybe 40 characters, all with bald heads and white whom you had to keep track of, so John and his girlfriend asked quite a bit "who is that?" or something similar... and I had the same problem at times. ANYWAY. Pretty long, and the "funny" things seemed a bit out of place. I always feel pretty shitty after seeing a "based on true story" movies because I question the validity of certain "holes in the plot" or other such things. Such as... at the end, the people who were fighting the entire time were forced to run alongside the convoy, while the fresh military men were sitting in there saying "sorry no room!"? Did that really happen? That one guy was wounded and he had to run all the way out of town. I mean really. I think... that's SHITTY if it's true, and if it's not... then what was the point? When they show all the casings hitting the ground towards the end... what was the point in that? Nothing, really. Things like that scream "RUSHED" to me. Also a few minor gripes about Josh Hartnett: He looks 17 in this film. His voice is cracking so much you'd think he just started puberty. He's leading them, yet he is taking orders from everyone else. He's looking to others for advice. He is weak and useless until the end. Most of the movie is him preaching. This movie did too much verbal preaching. I think certain moments where the sound stopped and the camera went to slo-mo you can see the point of the film.... but they kept on preaching. That was not necessary. Oh my god this mosquito bite is killing me. Other things to say: Okay I already mentioned the mosquito bite so that's out of the way... Sobe Nirvana is good stuff. I like songs by Sheila Nicholls. There is nothing cooler than seeing a girl's thong through her skirt. HOWEVER, there is nothing that ruins that moment worse than seeing her dad staring at the same thing you are. That's creepy and now it's no longer a fantasy, it's a sad/funny anecdote. Bah. I'm sad. Someone clean my mind of icky thoughts and replace them with nice dirty thoughts!

Like all of my big posts, this is extremely unpolished and probably makes no sense at all at times, but it's something that's been on my mind I want to talk about. All right now I know this is old hat for most people... to think yeah yeah the media controls the nation... but when you think about it, WE only think about how the media controls us in a major way, such as leftist propoganda, gender roles, etc. More and more lately I've been seeing what media is doing on a micro level -- as in, not just advertising products, but altering society to center around a certain product. What I have in mind in this case is rap music. I mean beer is beer; alcohol is alcohol and if you're going to get drunk, get drunk. But in the 1980s not only were impressional urban youths being told to consume something, they were being told that if they didn't, they did not belong. I was talking to residue last night about this (well, something marginally different, but we touched on this) that certain things are considered "black" or "white" or "asian" or "latino;" eg. hot sauce. I mentioned liking it and he said "I thought that was a black thing!" and I said "Oh, I just thought it was a fat thing..." Now that's just a tangent and not my point particularly, the point being that certain things are social "things," BUT WHY? How the hell is there a universal beverage for your race, or hat for your social circle? Why do people look at Zima and say "homo drink!" or Malt Liquor and say "AHAHA black drink!"? More importantly... why do all college students drink beer? Was it as common before Animal House? Yeeeah probably, but I do know that Animal House was the start of people thinking they HAD to do certain things in college: Join frat, drink lots of beer, dress in togas, and be promiscuous. It was no longer what benefitted you the most or was the most fun, it was the universal code. "Back then you didn't smoke weed because it was the thing to do, you smoked it because it got you high" --Willie Nelson in "Half Baked." Then the late 80s and early 90's roll around and rap stars talk about walking around with a joint or a blunt hanging out of their mouth. No longer was it a pasttime, it was a lifestyle. I go drinking on the weekends because I would prefer to handle the week sober, is that so wrong? Even in the black and white era of movies, there were two constants: 1, when you came home from a hard day's work, you poured yourself a glass of a nondescript alcohol, or, later, had yourself a beer. You know what I like to do after a hard day's work? Shower, drink something that quenches my thirst, and relax. What does alcohol do? It forces you to relax. If you are not relaxed after working hard, then maybe you should go do something else, because you're not exhausted and there's no reason to "wind down." :wtf: The other constant is cigarettes: When you're a guy and you smoke, you're cool. You're hip. You're aloof. When you're a woman and you smoke you're seductive, exotic and mysterious. Why is that? Because you have bad breath? Brown teeth? You wheeze like a pig? Your car stinks and has a bunch of burn holes on the driver's seat, and when your convertible is opened up the ashes fly out and get in people's eyes? I know you're probably thinking "Yeah yeah Bean, we know that already," but I was just giving the two classic examples of how the media forms a lifestyle. Perhaps later on I'll post something about gender roles (I've learned that there's a whole lot more to it than people think.), and perhaps later another topic.

Pit day! Ugh... so people who know me know I accidentally stayed up until 1:00 AM CST, for my 7:00 AM CST wakeup call, and ended up working till 7:00 PM CST. Okay so I wasn't exactly working the entire time... I'm still a bit shaky loading rocks into a dump truck, though I'm perfectly okay digging and sorting with the skid loader (aka bobcat, tiny front-end loader...?) So anyway, eventually I will be able to load myself... it's not about ability, I can do it fine and have in the past, but one time loading for my dad the ground was too bumpy and I tipped and scraped the back of his truck and ever since then I've been kind of afraid. ANYWAY not like you care. While out there I worked on my tan (gave my bald head some sun for the first time since I was a baby), and did some walking -- barefoot. Then while wading through the mud, I remembered that there are organisms that like to burrow through the bottom of your feet, and thought to myself... omg so like, am I gonna die from some microorganism now? That would TOTALLY suck. But I am not really worried since I don't care. Anyway, while walking I had a little bird nest pointed out to me in the middle of the rocks, and the eggs looked like rocks, and it was just in a little hole in the mud, and there was this baby bird there that appeared to be dead... but it wasn't... it was just playing dead because people were near. Its mother was about 10 yards away ruffling her feathers and screeching bloody murder to take our attention away from her nest. I thought that was sweet -- and very cool how nature works out like that. Anyway, after eating one of the eggs (just kidding), I went for my walk, and found an egg shell maybe 30 yards away from the nest, in some fresh mud. Iiiiinteresting. I also saw a pretty good-sized frog, with which I had a long staring contest.... but then I had to get back to work and scared it away :( If anyone's traveling through Minnesota let me know and I'll try setting up a day at the pit... it's perfectly quiet and beautiful. Especially today, as it was 85 degrees, no clouds, a light breeze and NO HUMIDITY finally. Today was the most perfectest day ever. xXx Here is something I posted on a message board, first regarding Vin Diesel as an actor, and second regarding the movie xXx itself. First of all what's this whole "HE IS NOT THAT HOT AND CAN'T ACT" bullshit? Arnold Sylvester :wtf: Which those two won an oscar, or a "sexiest man alive" award? Exactly! They had bodies. They could act like badasses. They're Vin Diesel. However, Vin imho looks better, is more "realistic" body-wise, has a cool voice AND a cool name, unlike his predecessors. Therefore, Vin superior, Arnold and Sly inferior. As for the movie... I liked it. It was just an underachieving yet promising first attempt at an American James Bond (Wedge told me this wasn't the first, but I stated that the plot and a lot of the movie were direct ripoffs of Bond, making it more of a direct replica, not just an answer to Bond). My problems with the film were first and very, very foremost the music. Cheesy and campy at times (if you felt the movie got a bit corny at times you were probably sucked into the music), and that was the score. The soundtrack -- the non-score songs -- were all misplaced. I could not feel any of the music in the film. They even had the corny "Bond-esque" music playing in real tense suspenseful moments, probably to create more levity, so that the crowd could have a "good time." I think a good huge chunk of the stunts were far too over-the-top, such as the motorcycle(motorbike?) scenes, where he basically jumped off the ramp of a building and was what, 5 stories up in the air, with the fire right on his back without damaging him or even knocking him off course, and he landed seemlessly and kept driving. I started feeling like someone turned the no-grav cheat on in a video game. Other than that, THIS WAS AN ACTION MOVIE! so you know, things like the convenience of a heat-seaking missile really weren't that ridiculous, considering how James Bond is a really shitty spy, since he always ALWAYS gets caught, and instead of escaping, most of the time people either let him live, or save him. Things like that remind me why action/spy movies are not supposed to be subjected to such rigorous scrutiny that people tend to use lately -- not just with these movies, but all movies. Every single movie is expected to make you think, yet it's the movies which try too hard to make you think and fail that are given the most applause. Pfffft.

While we're talking about childhood... I just wanted to ask yall if you have paid attention to the freshness of the minds of children? In fiction, we are being taught to make strange all of the everyday things we face, to treat the world as though it is an entirely new entity, much like a child upon witnessing the world for the first time. When Josh first started becoming aware, and able to make sounds (not quite talking), he and I would sit outside on the steps with him on my lap or on my shoulder, and he would look up at the sky and point (as he did in the video with his grandma). That is one of my favorite memories ever... me and Josh walking around, him pointing at things and me telling him what they were. Things we take for granted, like sidewalks, like bugs, like cars driving by on the street. A professor once said something about walking down a city street with a kid, and if you pay attention, the child will point out some of the strangest things we are trained to ignore. Things we are taught to be insignificant to our minds and imaginations. Libby posted on her site about teaching her cousin things, and oh my god nothing is greater than knowing you've taught a child new information (as I have just signed up to tutor Samantha), but I think the one thing greater than teaching a child, is learning from a child. As I said in my last "serious" post, Josh has taught me the importance of life. He as also taught me how to expand my world to include others -- when we go out, my eyes are always on him, and when they're not, he's never out of the corner of my eye. When I make decisions, I plan ahead to make sure he will be ok, and always prepare myself to handle Josh. Where are the exits? More importantly, WHERE ARE THE BATHROOMS? Because Josh is in my life, I am now losing weight. I want to be healthy. I want to be fit enough to play sports with him. I want to live long enough to see him blossom into a man, and see if my impression on him was strong enough to make him a good man. I don't want him to remember me as the fat uncle who never did anything, or the uncle he knew as a kid, but the uncle whose funeral he attended when he was 16, or the uncle who just isn't around anymore. I have told Josh, time and time and time again, "talk to me. Ask me anything you want to know." Now he asks. Oh, does he ever ask! And I answer. And when he asks, it forces me to rethink things. Things I take for granted. Why do I do this? Why do I do anything? There are explanations for everything, and if there is no explanation, then I have no reason to do something. He keeps me on my toes. He will challenge my ideas merely by asking "why?" and "why not?" and always presents me with an alternative. Why don't I choose the alternate route? Why do I do what I do, and not something else? And I laugh. I laugh because he's so smart, and because I'm so stupid, and because when he challenges me it makes me realize all the more why I love him. EVERYONE should have a Josh.

Jackass This isn't really a review. You really can't review this movie. This movie isn't really a movie. Jackass the movie is just a bunch of skits/segments/vignettes/outtakes/clips/whatever from the show Jackass; generally things they can't show on MTV, and in generally so so so much worse. In fact, if I was a prude or squeamish, I would definitely boycott this film. But as it stands, I really did enjoy it. It's every young white trash male's dream to do some of the things they do, as they make asses of themselves in public, hurt each other and themselves, get in lots of trouble and get really, really wasted. Don't let them fool you: When Johnny Knoxville gets really hurt doing... something, you see he is sitting on the ground drinking some mysterious brown liquid from a brown-tinted clear jar. HMMMMMMMMMMMMMM. Curiouser and curiouser. Anyway... it's definitely a movie you can't see alone, and one you have to own on video to play when you and friends are getting very drunk or otherwise fucked up. If you want to go see it again, I'll come with. I've forgotten a lot of the bits in it, but they were good. I really can't rate this film, even if I rated films ;) but Jackass is in a league of its own. It has no plot, no acting, per se, but you won't stop laughing for more than 30 seconds throughout the whole thing. That is what makes it special. Hobbled and hallucinating! Argh, it hurts me to try making headlines for my posts. Not that it's hard, I just find it so... presumptuous and pretentious as though my posts are some sort of gold that need a title in case someone cites me in a research paper or something. Ah hell, I'm too tired to dwell on that right now anyway. The paper I had to get done? Yeah, I started that at 1 am and finished at 5:15, before getting up at 8:15. Needless to say, my body didn't get a sufficient opportunity to heal itself from the stress I put it through during the day. To lose weight I have been walking instead of busing around campus, and up stairs instead of elevators, which has had a profound effect on me, but has also stressed me out pretty bad too. You see... when I had surgery in 91, they took out what, like 60% of the muscle of my knee area. This means I have no strength in my left quad, and all the stress goes on the joint, surrounding muscles, ligaments and cartilege. Nobody cares so I'll go on. I'm extra super loopy and I was just thinking of stuff I could discuss with yall, but I realized my focus is shrinking and I can't come up with anything on my own. My Lit Prof was discussing the Apocalypse today, and gave us a writing exercise: If the world was going to end in five minutes, what do you think those five minutes would be like? I said that (in my humblest of opinions) the first minute there would be silence. People would be letting it sink in. On the second minute, anyone who is prone to cry will start crying, and on the third and fourth minutes, anyone who can't cry will otherwise lash out. There will be suicides and random violence for two minutes, before, for the fifth and final minute, we would all watch and wait. This was me on three hours sleep at 9:45 AM mind you. If I was better rested, I would have said something about aliens for sure. What do you all think would happen if we had five minutes before the end of the world? Well my point is, my Lit professor is a morbid son of a bitch. He tells us stories of people dying all the time, and makes references to the DC Sniper and other such goodies to get his points across. Part of me thinks that's cool, that he's so open with his dark side, but there is a part of me that really can't stand it. This is a silent part of me that rears its ugly head every so often when confronted with the morbid or depressing. I used to have no fears and was as callous as you could be, but the night I stood in the hospital room as my grandpa died, something in me snapped. First of all, I became less superficially sensitive... less apt to feel bad about what people say about me... but on the other hand, I gained a respect for, and a hatred of death. A couple months later I came across a picture of a man... well, let's just say it was a morbid death picture. It made me feel nauseus -- but not in the stomach, but all over... just like every part of me was sick and wanted to throw up. Until recently, it kind of went away... but now I can't watch any tragedies on TV without getting that feeling -- even in my fiction class, when we read a Raymond Carver story about a couple pulling their child until it (allegedly) breaks, or is pulled apart. I couldn't bring myself to face the story. We had to write what we thought happened at the end, and I really, really didn't want to. I don't really like being sensitive about such things. I wish I could make it go away and be a cold bastard like I was meant to be, but I can't. The year before my grandpa died, Josh was born. In that short time, I finally had reason to respect life and death. I won't get into exactly why I'm at odds with my sensitive self lately. I was reintroduced to it recently by someone, but in the end I regretted it. Just leave it at that. Now I want to go club a baby seal. I couldn't do it, by any means, but damn do I ever want to.

When last we met... ...I was discussing the importance of nature, the expansive and unknown in my creative life. As time wore on, my grandpa's farm was shut down to me and my family. As a little kid, my great aunt had a huge farm in North Dakota and it was wonderful, because it had a little woods, and it had horses, and it had endless fields of flatness (as North Dakota does.) Grandpa's farm was full of hills, while this... was endless. Looking back, that's what I want. So I repeat: As time wore on, and I lost access to the farms, I took refuge on the water. When I can, I make a trip to Lake Superior during the summertime, and if I am allowed (most people find this boring), I will sit on the shore for as long as I possibly can and stare out at the water, and listen to the waves crashing, drowning out my thoughts. I've only been to the ocean once, christmastime 2000 in Florida. I never got to fully enjoy it because I feared the jellyfish, but it was most definitely refreshing to watch. Not yet since those bygone days on the farms have I had the chance to get lost in nature. The longer I go without, the more I feel myself be irreversibly emotionally drained. That being said, when I think of myself as a country or a city person, I am first, foremost and undeniably city. I couldn't survive a day in the country. I was born and raised in the city, and it's all I know. However, I really... I can't be comfortable here (I wrote a poem about this, it's in my writings section, amongst my retchedly horrible poetry, entitled I Wanna Go Home). Here comes the sentimental, fruity part. Sometimes I feel like a domesticated animal. I was not born free, but I have it in my blood. I have seen the wild and I want to be there, but I know I can't. All I know is my cage and captivity. I know being taken care of, security and no responsibilities. I'm completely dependent. This, of course, holds true for me in general, as I have yet to move out on my own, but basically it holds true for Nature. Nature is where I want to be, but I do not think it's where I belong. I don't know how to mediate between the two, and I don't know if I am ready to try. I think I'm starting to feel like the (Literary) Romantics who went on their pastorals or excursions into the woods to escape from the monotony of everyday city life. That somehow the rustic, simple existence justified and validated them. I'm a spoiled college student who knows only traffic congestion and graffiti and skyscrapers. Maybe a bit of the old rustic lifestyle would do me well. I am getting so fucking tired of worrying about tomorrow. I spend so much time dwelling on yesterday, that with the future, I've really got no time to dwell on anything new. I need a vacation. Not a vacation, an escape. I do not want to worry about things, I don't want to make decisions. I don't want "where shall we stay?" or "where shall we eat?" I want the most simple, unplanned escape where I don't have to make any decisions or worry. In short... I do not want to seek out, I want to discover. I want reactive instead of proactive. I want, if just for a few short hours, to regain that piece of my childhood where my imagination and my creativity were at their peak. And Jake, I don't want to be a kid again, I just want that one thing. I could verymuch do without wetting the bed, thank you very much. I think that's what I had to say. There is probably more, but I'll just leave it at that.

While I put off writing... Careful... this is going to be slightly fruity and sentimental, but well, it's something that I thought and may or may not believe -- with me, you can never be sure, right? But my art teacher said something about the environment which first inspired your creativity... the place where you can associate your creative self. Obviously she was talking about artists, but my being a writer(ha), can still relate. Growing up, the greatest places I could ever be were farms. Endless, expansive, new territory, at least to the younger me. I remember walking for what to me felt like hours and hours at my Grandpa's farm, through corn fields up hills, to the murky, frightening swamp. I would wear my shoes after a rain and get them caked with mud, and try to crack as much of the dried sheets of clay as I could; and when it was dry I would take my shoes off and wiggle my toes in the superfine sand on the roads. But most of all I loved the exploring. The coolest thing to a little kid back then was walking through a corn field and finding a burrow -- a flattening of some stocks of corn right in the middle of the field. We never knew what the hell it was. Every flattening or bunching of grass was a nest and every hole was a den, and there could be an animal nearby! As a kid, I wanted so badly to be an archaeologist, mainly because I love the dirt, I love to dig and I love finding things. It doesn't matter what it is, as long as I've never seen it before, I love it. Or I did back then. I've slowly been losing my creativity the last several years -- my grandpa had a stroke I believe in 1992, and he died almost exactly five years later. After his stroke, his son -- my uncle -- forbade anyone from going to the farm. Basically, it was gutted out and turned into a gravel pit, while more and more of the heart of my Grandpa's farm was ripped out and hauled somewhere. It's been over 10 years since I've had the chance to explore it. I know this isn't the reason for my creative lapse, but I know that it was definitely the disconnection of me from the place that inspired my creativity. I will cut it off here, in case you actually decided to read this post, I will say more later, because I have a bit more to rant about if you care. Until then, I've got a paper to (not) write. Later! PS: I am officially 38 lbs lighter than I was last time I was weighed. In celebration, I subsequently ate 10 pizzae. O_o

Since nobody has commented on any of my posts I take it nobody is reading, or those who are reading don't care. Well let me tell you something, sister. I don't care either! I've had major attitude the last few days so maybe it's best I haven't blogged, but then what do I care? It's fun shaking things up. Not that I plan on doing that. Whatever. Yesterday I had a big ole presentation to do for an art class, and I rocked at it. The rest of my group sucked because they didn't want to coordinate, and one of the guys didn't even do fuckall for it, but I helped everyone do better and hopefully that will reflect better on me. I got lots of "good job!"s from my teammates and teacher(+TAs), which was cool except I realized that I'm 22, in a class with a bunch of 18/19 year olds and I probably did much, much worse than I should be able to do at this level. He he he oh well. It was a blast. I spoke in front of a crowd and didn't faint. How's that for progress? Another thing I'd like to discuss is that today I was talking to a girl from my fiction class and we were gossipping about the teacher. She mentioned that whenever she talks about him he appears behind her and it freaks her out. We got on the bus and were still talking about him, though we were no longer talking shit, just saying what he did/said to us in conferences, and then after a few minutes I leaned down (as I was standing) and told her I hoped I wasn't too loud. She looked confused, so I pointed up at our teacher and said "Bob's right there." She freaked out. The man is like the villian in a horror movie. Not that he's a psycho killer, but he pops up randomly. The debate is, did he hear us? I don't know if he did, as we were pretty far back, but depending on how loud someone is, they resonate quite a bit and COULD be heard. I do not remember how loud we were, so I do not know if he heard us or not, as I only saw the back of his head. My question to you guys: How can I know if he heard? I feel really bad, because I was saying things we talked about in conference -- I didn't talk shit, per se, but I did pretty much engage in gossip and said some things I shouldn't have said, though they were mainly things I would say to his face if I had to. He's a pretty tough teacher, as I stated in an earlier post about him being a dick. He's not so much a dick, just very strict and rigorous which I can't fault him for, as that makes for better students. Anyway, I thought we were getting along all righttt, but if he heard me I have no idea what he may say or think. oOoOOoOh suspense. On a similar note, I have until the end of the month to write my next draft of my story. That's a lot of time, but I haven't started because I suck majorly. You kids take care now. And feel free not to reply, too.

Brain On Overdrive Okay I am going to ramble these things and they're going to make little sense, but lately my mind has just been working overdrive with all kinds of cool shit from school, from friends and from Minnesota politics, etc. First of all, I have a presentation due on Monday, and it's on Icons. The thing is, it's on four different aspects of the icon, and a half hour, and honestly I could talk for an hour on my article alone. There are four articles: The Image (wherein text and ideas give way to icons, and become obsolete); Icons (wherein we lose the significance of something unattainable and religions via icons, i.e. everything Christ embodies has been summed up in a cross, or a fish, and the emotion of love is iconified by a heart-shaped box, or a bouquet of roses); Place and its relation to Icons (Where we are from shapes how we view others, and how others view us: Basically a discussion of stereotyping and how it has simplified interpersional relations: We no longer see individuals, but types. We no longer have to deliberate the humanity of a person, because we know what kind of person they are because of the stereotype the media gives us. This idea is pretty old hat, though); Flags, and their relation: (Basically, the American flag is supposed to be an Icon. For those who burn the American flag, it is a symbol for everything that is wrong with America. For those who oppose flag burning, it is an icon for everything right. In my opinion, this fits in with all the other arguments because it is cheapening everything America stands for -- by turning it into a $.99 piece of nylon sold by the bushel at roadside stands after 9/11... it's just so cheapened that we can take a piece of cloth, use it as the icon for a stereotype of a group of individuals, and use the burning of a flag as a way to injure the stereotype. I think that if we were to realize that what people burn isn't us individually, but of the view of all Americans they have been granted because of a) where they live and b) where we live, then the burnings wouldn't be so offensive. And if we were not so uptight about flag burning, then it wouldn't be done so often, as it's only an attention ploy. It's late and I don't have time to keep going right now, so I'll talk about this or something else at a later time. I am the Icon of all things Beany. Oh yeah.

urlLink Josh and Sam (and John) Two Days After Thanksgiving WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!!! So I have a digital camera now, and you can expect lots of pictures to be uploaded (but none of me :P). These were the first pictures I took, really, and my cam only takes pictures of people! I'm still learning the ropes of it, but I'll figure it out eventually. Why do I have a digital camera? Well, a couple years ago my super awesome camera was in a plastic baggie in a cooler on the Apple River in Wisconsin with assorted alcoholic beverages, food, and melting ice. I saw that the camera had gotten wet so I asked if anyone had a baggie I could use (the camera still worked), and someone offered their baggie. By the way, I was extremely, extremely drunk, as the sun always heightens the buzz, but I couldn't really do anything for myself, so I let someone else put my camera in a baggie. Later on that day I looked and saw my camera in the water, inside an open sandwitch bag, and ARGH I was so pissed. I mean, I knew I should have been but I was a bit too drunk to really care, but I have been hurting ever since. Anyway, recently a camera repair person looked at it, and after hearing what was wrong with it she suggested that the circuitry was fried and it would cost $200.00 to fix it. Yeah. Not gonna happen. So my favoritest camera of all time is fucked. Does anyone out there know anyone who can fix cameras? :( Anyway, so this digi cam, when I got it, it was a pre-used version, and it was really shitty, and missing a bunch of stuff. So it was taken back, and when I opened the new box, there was no camera! Yeah, it was a display model, so it took three trips to the store to finally get it right, but I'm pretty happy. I would have been happier if I'd gone to Best Buy and picked up the super discounted ones on Friday. ARGH I was so torn apart by the after Thanksgiving sales, but I knew I'd end up paying more than I wanted to... and I knew the "mail-in rebates" would NEVER come, because the people in charge of that are bastards. :( So I've got a lot of homework to do, and I didn't do any all weekend. I've been too busy, after all. I didn't do anything that I couldn't have stopped to do my work, but I mean come on, if something comes up, I'll choose that over homework any day!

You know what really sucks? When everyone -- and I mean everyone -- around you are uptight, irritable, depressed or unhappy. I'm not very good at being the source of my own happiness. I need help from outside, and I'm just surrounded by people moping. I can't handle it. I've been depressed for like 15 years and I'm just now seeing the light at the end of the tunnel... I'm just now pulling myself out of depression, but now I know how everyone felt around me -- except times 20957024975. Now everyone's pulling me down with them, and that fucking sucks. It ain't worth it. I'm going to start blocking out, beginning now.

Bean's memory I did this for my first literary non-fiction assignment. I messed up bigtime, as it was supposed to be dwelling on a specific moment, and I didn't do that. I didn't even name it. It's just a great big failure, but I had way too much work to do, I was like 3529607205493 pages of reading behind last night so I had to do this earlier today... so... Sporadic Sundays growing up were spent in the great wilderness. My grandparents lived in the rural city of Lakeville; my grandpa and a great number of his neighbors were farmers. Across the street stood an endless field of corn, which now would have an end. Growing up in the cornless city of Minneapolis, I could only explore uncharted territory on these Sundays of my youth. During the daytime, we would play the country-folk games, because we were visitors my cousins lived out there. I can remember best the efficient production of authentic country Mud Pies. Take some dirt clods, and mix with water, then add your own personal touch to taste. Sometimes, when the lawn was justmowed, it would make an excellent vegetarian Mud Pie. For those of us who needed meat in our Mud Pies, we had to hunt for grasshopper. Across the street in the cornfield, we found a jungle of corny foliage, five times the size of us! It was filled with all kinds of wild beasts ladybugs, caterpillars, moths, but none so elusive as the wily grasshopper. Nobody would ever eat our pies, except for little Bob, who is maybe six years younger than me, and I am one of the youngest of the family. He would put anything in his mouth, and I dont think he has changed his ways as I am writing this, fifteen-plus years later. Maybe I fell for it once, and I blocked it out. Nobody wants to admit to eating mud, but everyone has done it. Its a rite of passage, and I would expect the older kids wouldnt let me play with them until I did. Now that I think about it, grass probably doesnt taste so bad, and dirt hey, its on the non-hydroponics vegetables we eat but a grasshopper? I doubt anyone would tell me the truth if I asked today, Of course you ate a grasshopper, Scott! Dont you remember? Who would? Back then (I was under five at the time), all memories are happy. If not, it couldnt be classified as childhood, rather everything after. (Self-pity didnt exist for me until a short while later.) We took our craft seriously, we prankster chefs for the five-star restaurant in our heads. There were no toys, no balls, and no other fun to be had outside, so we would play as long as we had daylight, stopping only when the pirates came out after sunset. The Pirates. Up, up in the sky above the corn, three spooky ghost pirate ships set sail. Never fearing the moon, stars or clouds, they just passed through the sky, looking for kids who were out too late. We would run and hide as they made their way from one end of space to the other, and the older kids would tell the younger kids, The pirates are going to get you! I dont remember who told me the searchlights were pirate ships, or even if I believed them. I just know that back then, the truth was irrelevant, because the fantasy was fun. Maybe once every month or so, my brothers and I would go with my mom to her parents house. We were forced to eat dinner in the basement, accompanied by the boxelder bugs, and we fought an awful lot. The adults fought just as much, or more, depending on how many Tom and Jerrys or Brandy-7s they drank. At the end of the day, we would drive silently home for a half hour, listening to Dr. Demento on the radio, and generally passing out two thirds of the way there. Anything bad was forgotten because life went on, and we were too busy to dwell, until much, much later.

Self-Conscious All my life I've heard the term "self-conscious" being used to describe a woman whose hips are getting too big, or someone with a pimple on their nose. Somehow, to the world around me and ultimately to me, the term "self-conscious" was a shameful adjective. Growing up I was the biggest range of adjectives. So big, in fact, that I could never put my finger on it. Was I self conscious but with a high self esteem? No... I had a low self esteem, that must have meant I wasn't self conscious... it wasn't until recently that I finally gained a grasp of who I am, emotionally. I am self conscious. That means I am self aware. That means I know what everyone else sees, and I think about how my actions affect others. I am conscientious(sp?), and considerate... when I do something that I wouldn't like if someone else did it, I stop. My life doesn't end at my own pleasure or convenience... ever. Is that not what it means to be self conscious? I have always told people "Yeah, I'm fat and ugly." And people say "awww don't be so hard on yourself!" and I say... am I complaining? You freaking asked me and I answered. Nobody ever tried lying to me and saying I looked good, and I do not run and hide at the thought of being me. Being morbidly obese, I still spent four years at college before I started losing weight. I knew, but I also knew that if I let my appearance get me down, I'd just get worse and end up nothing. It was realism, not self pity. BUT! Along with my self consciousness, came a low self-esteem. Esteem... sort of like respect. Can be taken to mean, regard, respect, value, whatever. My self worth was never very high. I put others' needs above my own -- my own happiness revolves around everyone else's happiness. I don't like anything I ever do, and don't trust myself, not in the least. I don't think I'm the best anything, unfortunately -- however I do believe I am the best something . Best something. That is my ego talking. I have a fragile ego based on years as the youngest child, being told I can do anything, be anything. I've always been told how I am the most artistic and the smartest in the family. High expectations? Not really. I stopped listening to criticism when I realized how often it would come from my Dad. Criticism doesn't work on me. Guilt trips don't work on me. Logic works on me, and I am anal about many things, like logic, language, manners, and other matters of taste. I can be downright rude if you don't meet my standards. My standards aren't so high, they're just particular. I am a snob, despite my best efforts. Unfortunately, I am easily shaken, if you know which buttons to push, and despite my best attempts to fill the gaps in my armor, my ego can still take significant blows. That's what happens when it's so big -- more surface area. Easier to damage. It's like a puffer fish. It's big for show, but it's just full of hot air. :( Or salt water, whatever you want to believe... But this is all rambling besides the idea of self-consciousness. Why is that considered a bad thing? Everyone, it seems, around me at all times will sooner step on your toes than look down. They will pile yard upon yard of shit on top of something you're looking for. They will associate the first quarter of your story to the full length of theirs -- in excruciating detail. They will answer their cell phone in a study lab, or cut you off in traffic, or jay walk, or walk on red. They go to dinner knowing full well they can't afford it, so they let the waitress pay the difference, and leave her tipless. They are the reason I have to carry Josh in busy stores and streets. They are the reason the shy will never have their opinion heard -- there is no world outside of these people. They are not self conscious. They are self-contained. To be self conscious, is to see yourself and what you are doing. To be self contained means your head is up your own ass, and you can only smell roses.

Not Bad... I was just thinking about my life, and how for so long my life was horrible, and I was very unhappy, and horrible to be around. Nothing anybody did could change how I felt, and I was at rock bottom for years. After I finally pulled myself out, after my hell was over, my life still was no good... I was still alone, still lonely, still hurting and sad. I was complacent with my place in life, because it could be worse. I was no longer on rock bottom, so I somehow thought it was okay to be justabout there. Now here I am today. My life is better. I'm living healthier, my self image is better, I'm no longer constantly depressed, but I'm still alone, and I'm still lonely. I'm sitting here typing on the computer instead of going out and finding friends. I want friends I can show my website, so I can hide all my internet friends from them out of shame. (cough) The sad thing is, that I always look outside myself first, and looking at other people I see things about myself in them, which makes me more aware of my own problems. I know too many people who will tell me, about their place in life (specifically relationships), "well it's better than it used to be," or "it could be worse." I know people who say "I can't do any better," as though they know. They, like me, are getting older, and losing their opportunities to live life to its full potential. The sad thing is, most people are in this boat. If you can't be with the one you love, love the one you're with. Where is the happiness in that? Why won't we strive to be happy, for fear that we cannot reach it? For most, being alone is so unfathomable... so painful... that they will marry the first person to show interest in them. I want to take this opportunity to threaten to kill Hollywood Romance movie makers, i.e. Nora Ephron, for their campy, fruity, unrealistic, idealistic movies that tell people how love happens, how true love finds a way, and how everyone is destined to find their soulmate whether they look or not. I've given up looking. I don't believe in soulmates or love at first sight. I can't believe in love at first sight, because nobody would fall in love with me at first sight; so if it exists, then I'm doomed! I think soulmates are just people with whom you're compatible. If you're normal, you have millions of soulmates. If you're odd, the closest thing you can find is someone with a similar heart. Heart and mind aren't soul. Did you just say I'm rambling? All I want out of life is to see the people I love be happy. When that doesn't happen, I hurt inside because I want to change that. I want to make them happy. However, there's nothing I can do to help anyone who isn't happy, when it comes to love. People who are settling are too busy trying to convince themselves it's the right thing to do that anything you say will be taken as hostility. People who don't know anything better, well, they have to save themselves or they'll never be saved. But I want to save them... But I can't. Is a heavy heart the reward you get for wanting everyone to be happy? Do I close myself off, and become self-centered, to make myself happy? I am so worried about other people doing whatever it takes, maybe it's time I took my own advice. I don't see any alternatives. I've got a similar post I'll post later. One much less.......... specific.

Pipe Dreams... My brother, Jay, father of Josh and Sam, has always been a dreamer. His dreams are many: He wanted to be a skateboarder, of course; but most importantly he's always wanted to be an entrepreneur. He's suggested a strip club, and many different mechanic/service-related businesses. Recently, however, he told me his dream since he was a kid was to buy, maintain and live on a marina. Well this came up at an opportune time, since in the next sentence he says to me "There's a marina for sale on the Saint Croix River. Dad says I should go for it. We could get it and all live there." I like the idea. The marina would mean, we would have a dock to stow boats (and make a good profit from that), and there would be food and lodging as well. If we played our cards right, the rednecks would come for the major warm-weather holidays and the money would roll in! Problems lie, however, in the cost, and, well, the lack of an entreprenurial history for my family. It's a great dream, but we would need a lot of help starting it up. First of all, it's either one, or one point five million dollars to purchase, not including the money it would cost to get it ready to reopen, and to stock etc. We could stand to lose a lot of money like with all businesses, but if we were to stay afloat, that is easy living for all of us. It would be easy for many reasons: First of all, with whatever loan we take out, we could pay a good chunk of it back with my mom's house and Jay's house, and with some of Jay's equipment that he would sell, so he could only haul boulders for a big firm (for big money). Also, the family will be coming into a sum of money I won't discuss here because it's secret, but I think we could be OKAY in that department, depending on how long the plan is to last. Anyway, there is a moral dilemma: Do I work to get this dream of Jay's fulfilled, thus leading me and mine to a life of general ease and security? If we go through with this, that leaves my brother John, who just graduated and is looking for a job, and me, working for family for life. That's a bad thing, right? I mean, we will never learn independence or "how to make it in the real world," if we get a job because of our relation... and don't have to worry about losing it, unless we lose the marina. Anyway, that's a problem. But... It would be so so so cool to be associated with this marina, it would be potential for many story-worthy experiences, and it would be so much easier than having to go out in the career world, if it was to work. I just need some confidence that it will work, and I need to pass that on to Jay, because while he has always been a lofty dreamer, reality always stares him in the face and keeps him from realizing any of his dreams. I would like to think this would make him happy finally, to live his dream... but none of us have stuck our necks out this far, so it is a lot to ask for all of us to do it... what do you think?

Crutches Originally posted five minutes ago on a message board by me. I was just humming an old song to myself tonight, a song that I once called my "theme song," the song I used as the theme for my life at a certain point, and I listened to it often as a reminder of how my life was, and what happened that was so significant. All the decisions I made were to counteract my theme song, and led to a new theme song. This got me to thinking: I don't have a theme song anymore! I have none! After all this time, music has just not been there for me; I haven't needed it. My theme songs in the past were all there for me to look to the past, to relive my past mistakes and dwell on them and never make any progress. Now, without a theme song, I am happier than I've ever been, and I am dropping my crutches like Forrest Gump when he started running. My first crutch, as you all know, was food. I'd run and hide when my parents fought and would drink lots of milk, and much on slices of bologna or cheese. Yeah, real healthy. Anyway, I've always blamed food, always gone to food to cheer me up -- when my adrenaline pumps I always have an instinctive reaction to just grab some food... when I'm excited, or scared... I guess it stems back to the fights. Anyway, recently, I've had so many excuses about my appearance, and why it is as bad as it is. My excuses just made me more confident in my depressive state, and in a constant state of despair with regard to my weight. I mean jesus christ, I was over 300 lbs. How can you fix that? But then the due man saved the day. Told me, if I cared about how I looked, I'd change it. No ifs ands or buts, I'd change it and that's that. I stopped looking at food and started looking at me: At where I wanted to be, and how I wanted to get there. For once I looked forward. No theme song, no excuses. Another major crutch I've been leaning on was this desire to fill the hole that is inside of me... my depression made me feel as though I needed someone else to complete me, to make me whole. I tried, and I tried, and I was always looking like a big fruitcake at school, just looking at the girls who were nice to me and wondering... why? Yeah. Real mature, right? So I didn't even consciously stop looking, it just happened. This has all happened at once. I snapped, in a way. All my crutches were thrown down and I can look forward, and all my depression problems, and what I thought was "seasonal affect" just aren't here. I am happy now, in the winter. Finals didn't stress me out.... much.... I have my puppy who is all the woman I need (shut UP you know I don't mean it like that), and as of last week, the scale said I'd lost at least 60 lbs. I'm not buying that it's 60 lbs just yet because it wasn't the Dr's office scale, but I am slimmer than I've been since I was like, 12, and feelin pretty good. The dog pissed in my shoes with the insoles in them, so my knees have been a little wonky, but other than that, I'm extremely happy. Life with no excuses truly is great. Okay, I admit life isn't so great, but if you could only get a glimpse of where I was 10 years ago, and 5 years ago, and then last April... It was pathetic. The worst part was, I didn't handle it well. I'm handling life well now. It's 4 am and I am really, really incoherent so what was supposed to be an intelligent post may just come out as a bunch of jumbled words, but I hope I get my point across. If your life isn't so great, or you're not so happy, and you have an excuse for it... stop. Excuses are crutches. Anything to make you look to the past is unhealthy. Pick a future and stay focused there. Every day you are closer to reaching your goal, is like Christmas. I do so love the new Bean.

Ive been sitting here at Peters Grill ever since a few minutes to 3:00 p.m., when she and I were supposed to meet here. I recall wondering if I should phone and remind her of our get-together before I saw my psychiatrist this morning. I decided not to, and I see it was a mistake. I dont have time to waste, and Im sure she doesnt either. I wonder what the problem is. Its expensive here, but Id better order something and spend a good long time waiting for her. Im hungry anyway. Its 3:25 p.m. I suppose Ill leave around 4:00 p.m. if my waitress hasnt asked me what I want to order, or should I wait until 4:30 p.m.? Its 3:40 p.m. Ive ordered. Ill stay as long as seems appropriate. 2 Mrs. Kuves voice sounds like shes my worst enemy, or his disciple. I consider Mark Forester my worst enemy and my daughters worst enemy. I see Mark as a worse enemy to democracy than any other person I know. He seems to do what he does because he has a grudge against me, but there may be deeper reasons why he does what he does. I wouldnt trust him with a nuclear push button. I dont consider Byron as dangerous to democracy as Mark, but then I havent seen Byron as someone in law enforcement might see him.

Yeah, yeah, I'm almost 23... what was I doing sledding yesterday? It's so obvious, I don't have to tell you why I went, or with whom. I'll just cut right to the chase. Last week we went. Sam wanted to go in her sled with me... surprising, that I even fit in a sled at all, but with a kid in there as well, well... that's always nice. I had my dress pants on. I hadn't entirely planned on going sledding. They are a thin material and very baggy -- most baggy at the bottom, where my ankles are almost bony. Anyway, my legs, as long as they are, had to hang off the end of the small child's sled, and as we went down, the wind blew up and inflated my pant legs, filling them with ice-cold air and snow. It was amazing. Don't get me wrong, I HATE sledding. I can't stand anything that raises my blood pressure. I feel... exhilirated and disgusted at the same time. It's just hard on me. So I rarely sled. I went once the first time, once the second time. Whenever I go to Valleyfair (like a ghetto Six Flags), I will ride the flume once, and only once, and that will be it, FOR THE YEAR. I'm a pussy. The kids were lined up at the only remaining patch of clean snow. The rest of the hill had been stripped clean of all the weekend snow by the early-morning kids of that morning, and the morning before. A bunch of older kids, 11ish, some not wearing coats (what the hell?) were racing... roughly. They would fight, knock each other down, pile up on sleds... very dangerous. It wasn't good to see, with Josh and Sam there. But the kids got their sledding in, but since they don't really get out much, they didn't have the endurance to walk up the hill as much as they wanted, so we were cut kind of short. New to the sledding scene, both would start walking up the track and we would have to yell "JOSH! SAM! GET OUT OF THE WAY! GO OVER HERE!" and it took them FOREVER. It was quite scary, but no harm done. There was a scary moment, however... Sam was going down, and she plowed right into Josh, knocking him over. She clipped his shin. My heart stopped. However, his grandma just bought him new boots, and he's a tough little bugger, so he got up and was AOK. Whew. Along with the sled and the snow tube, we brought Josh's snow skate, that I bought him for his birthday in November. It's basically a snowboard without footholds... or a skateboard without wheels. Anyway, there was a shallow hill before the walkway before the steep hill, and I offered to take Josh boarding down that hill. Well, Josh is five. Josh can't exactly snowboard, so he gave me one of his hands and I had to run down behind him, holding him up while he boarded down the hill. Oh, did he ever love that. Yeah, apparently my legs didnt. From the trips up the hills we made, and from running down the hill, and all this in my NON-supportive boots, and without a knee brace... well my legs are screaming at me today. And this was my big walking day, with my full backpack. Torture, man. My brother John made it down the hill on the snowskate... said it freaked him out; too fast. My turn came, and I went about a foot and stopped. Uh uh. No fucking way, man. That's not me. I don't want to die on a snowy hill, okay? I'll leave the fun to the kids. I caught some video of it... so with any luck, I'll be able to convert it to computer video... but that may not be for a while. Yall take care. Do you like the letters from the crazy lady? I know I'm going to hell for posting them... but what good would they be if I couldn't share with the world? I got offered money for everything tonight... it's amazing. Some pictures, some poetry, a couple book reports, letters to a psychologist, letters to her daughter, love letters to her obsession, an envelope containing evidence that the government was plotting against her... a newsletter to all her "people" about how her life is going... and most wonderful of all, one full notebook full of journal entries, and a few other notebooks with about a week's worth of journal entries. You guys better keep up, AlphaBean.net won't be boring for quite some time...
